5734055144325120.content:
The Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) is a multiple-choice test, administered by the United States Military Entrance Processing Command, used to determine qualification for enlistment in the United States Armed Forces. The ASVAB tests are designed to measure aptitudes in four domains: Verbal, Math, Science and Technical, and Spatial.

Our thousands of FREE ASVAB practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to passing your ASVAB. We divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini-game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

 About ASVAB exam

How many questions is the ASVAB test?

In total, the computer-based ASVAB has 145 questions, while the paper-based ASVAB has 225 questions. Both versions of the ASVAB are organized into a number of different subtests, all of which have a different number of questions that must be completed in a specific time limit.

What type of math is on the Asvab?

The two ASVAB tests pertaining to math are Arithmetic Reasoning and Math Knowledge. Arithmetic Reasoning is the ability to solve arithmetic word problems. Math Knowledge is the knowledge of high school mathematics principles.

How Long Does the ASVAB Take?

In total, the time limit for the entire Computerized ASVAB test is 2 hours and 34 minutes, spanning 145 questions. However, research shows that most ASVAB test takers do not need to use up the full allotted time limits per each section and move through at a typically faster pace.

Do you get your Asvab score immediately?

On average, it takes about 2 hours to complete the CAT-ASVAB. Your test scores will be available immediately following your testing session at the MEPS or MET site.

How many times can you take the Asvab?

To retake the ASVAB any times after that a six month wait is necessary between any ASVAB test retakes. To summarize that, you could theoretically take the ASVAB test three times in a three month period.

Do they drug test when you take the Asvab?

Recruits will take the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) test to determine which job they're most qualified for in the military, and will undergo medical examinations, which include a urine test to screen for drugs.

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

5296397775536128.content:
The GED test is consist of 4 subjects, broken into separate exams: Math, Reasoning Through Language Arts, Science, and Social study. These tests are designed to ensure that individuals who earn their GED have the skills and knowledge equivalent to high school graduates. You don’t have to take all 4 tests at once - you can space them out however it suits you and go at your own pace.

Our thousands of FREE GED PRACTICE QUESTIONS and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to passing your TEAS. We divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

There are 4 sections in the GED exam:

·       Mathematics – The math test is taken by all applicants by 115-minute test in length. Two main components of the Mathematics GED test are Algebraic problem solving and quantitative problem solving. An on-screen calculator is allowed during the Math section of the GED test. Do not bring your own calculator from home.

·       English and Language Usage – You will have 150 minutes to finish this section. This test concentrates on assessing a student's reading and writing skills. Questions are concerned with the Reading for Meaning, Identifying and Creating Arguments, Grammar and Language.

·       Social study: This is the shortest test of 4 GED tests within 70 minutes. The Social Studies GED exam covers 4 main topics. You will be tested on your knowledge of economics, U.S. history, civics and government and geography and the world. The civics and government test questions make up 50% of the test. Twenty percent of the test covers U.S. history, and the remainder of the test is divided between economics and geography and the world

·       Science: In this section, you will have 90 minutes to complete the test. The GED Science test covers three major topics: Reading for Meaning in Science, Designing and Interpreting Science Experiments, Using Numbers and Graphics in Science.

 

About TEAS exam

Is GED test hard?

The GED test is hard because it is very time-pressured. But if you prepare with good resources, the GED is quite easy. The GED test gives you limited time (from 70 to 150 minutes, depending on the subject) for around 35-40 questions per subject. The GED test is also easy because it is NOT tricky. The GED is a pretty straightforward test; you can easily get ready for it in a few weeks or months (depending on your educational background). Many GED test-takers end up feeling that they could have done much better if they only had more time.

 

Is GED math hard?

The GED test can be more difficult than exams in high school. It would require you to make use of your critical thinking abilities instead of just memorizing the facts. The questions do not merely require “yes” or “no” answers. You'll need to connect various concepts, analyze specific data and make inferences as well.

 

Can I take my GED test online at home?

No, you cannot take the GED test online. You may take preparation courses on the Internet, but you can only take the GED test in a GED testing service center. The GED test is generally administered on a computer, but you cannot take it online at home from your computer.

 

How to pass the GED test?

The bulk of what you'll need to know for the GED test is tied to the foundational education subjects commonly found in high school curriculums. The test covers material that students are expected to have acquired from their secondary education in the following areas: Reading, Mathematics, Social study, English.

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

free-ged-practice-tests-2020.content:
The GED test is consist of 4 subjects, broken into separate exams: Math, Reasoning Through Language Arts, Science, and Social study. These tests are designed to ensure that individuals who earn their GED have the skills and knowledge equivalent to high school graduates. You don’t have to take all 4 tests at once - you can space them out however it suits you and go at your own pace.

Our thousands of FREE GED PRACTICE QUESTIONS and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to passing your TEAS. We divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

There are 4 sections in the GED exam:

·       Mathematics – The math test is taken by all applicants by 115-minute test in length. Two main components of the Mathematics GED test are Algebraic problem solving and quantitative problem solving. An on-screen calculator is allowed during the Math section of the GED test. Do not bring your own calculator from home.

·       English and Language Usage – You will have 150 minutes to finish this section. This test concentrates on assessing a student's reading and writing skills. Questions are concerned with the Reading for Meaning, Identifying and Creating Arguments, Grammar and Language.

·       Social study: This is the shortest test of 4 GED tests within 70 minutes. The Social Studies GED exam covers 4 main topics. You will be tested on your knowledge of economics, U.S. history, civics and government and geography and the world. The civics and government test questions make up 50% of the test. Twenty percent of the test covers U.S. history, and the remainder of the test is divided between economics and geography and the world

·       Science: In this section, you will have 90 minutes to complete the test. The GED Science test covers three major topics: Reading for Meaning in Science, Designing and Interpreting Science Experiments, Using Numbers and Graphics in Science.

 

About TEAS exam

Is GED test hard?

The GED test is hard because it is very time-pressured. But if you prepare with good resources, the GED is quite easy. The GED test gives you limited time (from 70 to 150 minutes, depending on the subject) for around 35-40 questions per subject. The GED test is also easy because it is NOT tricky. The GED is a pretty straightforward test; you can easily get ready for it in a few weeks or months (depending on your educational background). Many GED test-takers end up feeling that they could have done much better if they only had more time.

 

Is GED math hard?

The GED test can be more difficult than exams in high school. It would require you to make use of your critical thinking abilities instead of just memorizing the facts. The questions do not merely require “yes” or “no” answers. You'll need to connect various concepts, analyze specific data and make inferences as well.

 

Can I take my GED test online at home?

No, you cannot take the GED test online. You may take preparation courses on the Internet, but you can only take the GED test in a GED testing service center. The GED test is generally administered on a computer, but you cannot take it online at home from your computer.

 

How to pass the GED test?

The bulk of what you'll need to know for the GED test is tied to the foundational education subjects commonly found in high school curriculums. The test covers material that students are expected to have acquired from their secondary education in the following areas: Reading, Mathematics, Social study, English.

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

5722070642065408.content:
You're looking for a good CDL practice tool? You're confused which one is good and fits your limited time? We are right there!

Our thousands of FREE Commercial driver license practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to beginning an exciting career in trucking. From dump truck to passenger bus and even tractor trailer CDL driver training in all states, we divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

This is the topics covering in our free practice tools based on the CDL handbook:

·       General Knowledge – The general knowledge CDL test is taken by all applicants with 50 multiple choice questions. It covers the general topics such as the rules of having a CDL, how to drive a commercial safely, safe transportation of cargo, and pre-trip inspections.

·       Air Brakes – If you plan on driving a vehicle with air brakes, you must take the air brakes CDL test. The air brakes test concludes 25 multiple choice questions. Topics on the air brake test will include: parts of an air brake system, dual air brakes, inspecting air brake systems, and using air brakes. This test can be taken by A, B, and C license holders.

·       Hazardous materials: This endorsement test includes 30 multiple choice questions covering these topics: intent of the regulations, communication rules, loading and unloading, bulk packaging marking, driving and parking rules, and emergencies. This testing ensures that you are fully trained and qualified to deal with potentially dangerous situations.

·       Passenger Vehicles – The Passenger Endorsement Test is required for drivers who plan on driving any vehicle designed to carry 16 or more persons, including the driver. This endorsement CDL test will have 20 multiple choice questions covering the following topics: vehicle inspection, loading and trip start, on the road, after-trip vehicle inspection, prohibited practices, and use of brake-door interlocks.

·       Combination vehicles: The combination vehicles test will have 20 multiple choice questions covering on couple and uncouple trailers, pulling double/triple trailers, doubles/triples air brake checks, and inspections.

·       Double and Triple Trailer Endorsement: This endorsement test is required for any drivers pulling double or triple trailers. The test has 20 multiple choice questions on how to couple and uncouple trailers, pulling double/triple trailers, doubles/triples air brake checks, and inspections.

·       Tanker vehicles endorsement: If you are planning on driving a truck that carries liquids or liquid gas in excess of 1,000 gallons or more, this endorsement is required. The materials do not have to be hazardous

·       School bus endorsement: If you want to get a school bus endorsement, you need to have a thorough understanding of such topics as danger zones, use of mirrors, loading and unloading, emergency exit and evacuation, railroad-highway crossings, student management, antilock braking systems, and special safety considerations.

·       Pre-trip inspections: This practice test will prepare you for the internal and external portions of the vehicle inspection exam, where you will be expected to be able to walk around your vehicle, touch items and explain to the examiner why items must be inspected before a trip.

Types of Commercial Driver's License?

There are three types of CDL classes that determine the type of vehicle you may drive and how much you may tow: Class A, B and C.

·       Class A (Combination Vehicles): Any combination of vehicles with a gross combination weight rating (GCWR) of at least 26,001 pounds provided the gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of the vehicle(s) being towed exceeds 10,000 pounds. Examples include tractor-trailers.

·       Class B (Heavy Straight Vehicles): Required to operate any single vehicle that isn’t hitched to a trailer (commercial trucks that have an attached cab and cargo area with a combined weight greater than 26,000 pounds, as well as trucks with a detached towed cargo vehicle that weighs less than 10,000 pounds). Such as Straight trucks, Large buses (city buses, tourist buses, and school buses), Segmented buses.

·       Class C (Small Vehicles): Required to operate a single vehicle with GVWR of less than 26,001 pounds or a vehicle towing another vehicle that weighs less than 10,000 pounds, or transports 16 or more passengers, including the driver. Example includes Double/Tripe Trailers, Buses, Tank Trucks, HazMat Vehicles        

How may CDK endorsements are there?

There are several endorsements that can be added to your CDL as well:

  • P: Passenger Vehicles. This requires a skills and knowledge test. This endorsement allows you to drive a vehicle carrying more than a specific number of occupants, depending on your state.
  • N: Tank Vehicles. This requires a knowledge test.
  • T: Double/Triple Trailers. This requires a knowledge test
  • H: Hazardous Materials. This requires a knowledge test and the TSA Threat Assessment.
  • S: School Bus. This requires a skills and knowledge test.
  • X: Tank Vehicle/Hazardous Materials Combination.

Tips for preparing CDL exam:

Review your state requirements for getting a CDL and obtain the CDL Manual for your state.

Find Out What to Study and collect your study materials

Find easy study strategies that work for you.

Practice, practice and practice with our free practice questions

Be focused and alert when you take the exam.

General Knowledge – The general knowledge DMV test is taken by all applicants by multiple choice questions. It covers the general topics regarding rules of the road, traffic signs, and driving laws.

Signs & Road Situations –Test your knowledge on the meanings of traffic and road signs. The test concludes several multiple choice questions, written in a very similar manner to those on the actual DMV written exam, that cover not only road signs but also general road rules, so be sure you study all relevant sections in the lastest Driver Handbook

Fines and limits: This endorsement test includes multiple choice questions covering these topics: information about fines, penalties, DUI regulations, and reasons a driver might lose his or her driving privileges. This testing ensures that you are fully trained and qualified to the rules of the road and what will happen if you break them.

What is on the DMV test?

The written portion of the official DMV test will also cover information from the Driver Handbook and ask questions covering rules of the road, traffic signs, and driving laws. The questions correctly you must answer verifies from state to state.

Tips for preparing for the DMV exam:

  • Review your state driver handbook. It contains all the information you need and it may take you a few days to get through it.
  • Go online and find yourself a practice test to gauge where you are at.
  • Get plenty of sleep the night before the test, and eat a healthy breakfast.
  • Read the test questions carefully. Don't read anything extra into the question. There will be 1 correct answer and the other two answer choices will be either obviously wrong or not appropriate for the question asked.
  • When you come to a question you don't know, relax and pick the best answer.
  • Remember, all the test questions are taken from the driver handbook.
  • Be confident. DMV wants you to pass your test. Good Luck!

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

5186025303310336.content:
The test measures your general knowledge of four subjects: Mathematics, Science, English and Language Usage, and Reading. The latest updated version is the ATI TEAS (also referred to as the TEAS 6). There are 2 versions of the test: electronic and paper and pencil. The type of test you take depends on where you are taking it. The content on the test is the same no matter which version you take.

Our thousands of FREE TEAS practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to passing your TEAS. We divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

There are 4 sections in TEAS 6:

·       Mathematics (22%)– The math test is taken by all applicants by 36 questions within 54 minutes. Topics covered come from areas of math that you should have studied during grades 7 through 12 in school. It covers the general topics regarding numbers, operations, data interpretation, algebra, and measurement. A four-function calculator is allowed during the Math section of the ATI TEAS test. One will be included in the online version and you will be issued one at the testing center during a paper and pencil test. Do not bring your own calculator from home.

·       English and Language Usage (16%)– The test concludes 28 questions and you will have 28 minutes to finish this section. Questions are concerned with the conventions of standard English, basic language and grammar knowledge, and vocabulary competence.

·       Reading (31%): The TEAS Reading test will evaluate your skills in paragraph comprehension and informational source comprehension. This test includes 53 questions to complete in 64 minutes. To do well, you need to be able to read for comprehension of key ideas, as well as details. Questions regarding the author’s purpose, style, and point of view is also concluded. Finally, you will be asked to take the knowledge you gain from reading and extend it through strategies such as prediction and analysis.

·       Science (31%): In this section, you will have to answer 53 questions in 63 minutes. The ATI TEAS Science test covers four major topics: scientific reasoning, life science, earth and physical science, and human body science.

 

About TEAS exam

What does the TEAS exam consist of?

Here's some good news—the format of the TEAS test is similar to other standardized tests you've likely taken in your life and shouldn't throw you for a loop. According to the Assessment Technologies Institute (ATI), the TEAS test consists of 170 multiple-choice questions covering a variety of subjects to be answered in 209 minutes.

 

How many questions are on the TEAS exam?

The ATI TEAS test is comprised of 170 questions set up in a multiple-choice format with four-option answers. Questions are designed to test the basic academic skills you will need to perform in class in the areas of: Reading, Math, Science, and English and Language Usage.

 

Can I use calculator in Teas test?

The ATI TEAS, being released August 31, 2016, will allow for the use of a four function calculator. Please do not bring your own calculator as a calculator will be embedded within the online version of the exam. For paper pencil versions of the TEAS test, the testing center will provide a four-function calculator.


How to pass the TEAS test?

The bulk of what you'll need to know for the TEAS test is tied to the foundational education subjects commonly found in high school curriculums. ATI shares that the test covers material that students are expected to have acquired from their secondary education in the following areas: Reading, Mathematics, Science, English.

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

5082322646859776.content:
You're looking for a good DMV practice tool? You're confused about which one is good and fits your limited time? We are right there!

Our thousands of FREE driver license practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you in the right direction to passing your DMV. We divide each knowledge domain into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini-game with fully detailed explanations for each question!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

General Knowledge – The general knowledge DMV test is taken by all applicants by multiple choice questions. It covers the general topics regarding rules of the road, traffic signs, and driving laws.

Signs & Road Situations –Test your knowledge on the meanings of traffic and road signs. The test concludes several multiple choice questions, written in a very similar manner to those on the actual DMV written exam, that cover not only road signs but also general road rules, so be sure you study all relevant sections in the lastest Driver Handbook

Fines and limits: This endorsement test includes multiple choice questions covering these topics: information about fines, penalties, DUI regulations, and reasons a driver might lose his or her driving privileges. This testing ensures that you are fully trained and qualified to the rules of the road and what will happen if you break them.

What is on the DMV test?

The written portion of the official DMV test will also cover information from the Driver Handbook and ask questions covering rules of the road, traffic signs, and driving laws. The questions correctly you must answer verifies from state to state.

Tips for preparing for the DMV exam:

  • Review your state driver handbook. It contains all the information you need and it may take you a few days to get through it.
  • Go online and find yourself a practice test to gauge where you are at.
  • Get plenty of sleep the night before the test, and eat a healthy breakfast.
  • Read the test questions carefully. Don't read anything extra into the question. There will be 1 correct answer and the other two answer choices will be either obviously wrong or not appropriate for the question asked.
  • When you come to a question you don't know, relax and pick the best answer.
  • Remember, all the test questions are taken from the driver handbook.
  • Be confident. DMV wants you to pass your test. Good Luck!

There is a lot to know and our free practice test for the DMV test will help you find out where you need to work more and make the most of your study time.

free-asvab-practice-tests-2020.content:
The Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) is a multiple-choice test, administered by the United States Military Entrance Processing Command, used to determine qualification for enlistment in the United States Armed Forces. The ASVAB tests are designed to measure aptitudes in four domains: Verbal, Math, Science and Technical, and Spatial.

Our thousands of FREE ASVAB practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to passing your ASVAB. We divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini-game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

 About ASVAB exam

How many questions is the ASVAB test?

In total, the computer-based ASVAB has 145 questions, while the paper-based ASVAB has 225 questions. Both versions of the ASVAB are organized into a number of different subtests, all of which have a different number of questions that must be completed in a specific time limit.

What type of math is on the Asvab?

The two ASVAB tests pertaining to math are Arithmetic Reasoning and Math Knowledge. Arithmetic Reasoning is the ability to solve arithmetic word problems. Math Knowledge is the knowledge of high school mathematics principles.

How Long Does the ASVAB Take?

In total, the time limit for the entire Computerized ASVAB test is 2 hours and 34 minutes, spanning 145 questions. However, research shows that most ASVAB test takers do not need to use up the full allotted time limits per each section and move through at a typically faster pace.

Do you get your Asvab score immediately?

On average, it takes about 2 hours to complete the CAT-ASVAB. Your test scores will be available immediately following your testing session at the MEPS or MET site.

How many times can you take the Asvab?

To retake the ASVAB any times after that a six month wait is necessary between any ASVAB test retakes. To summarize that, you could theoretically take the ASVAB test three times in a three month period.

Do they drug test when you take the Asvab?

Recruits will take the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) test to determine which job they're most qualified for in the military, and will undergo medical examinations, which include a urine test to screen for drugs.

free-cdl-practice-tests-2020.content:
You're looking for a good CDL practice tool? You're confused which one is good and fits your limited time? We are right there!

Our thousands of FREE Commercial driver license practice questions and tests will ensure that you are completely prepared, taking you to the right direction to beginning an exciting career in trucking. From dump truck to passenger bus and even tractor trailer CDL driver training in all states, we divide each knowledge domains into small parts. All you need to do is taking your study round by round as a mini game with fully detailed explanations for each questions!

Practice with us and get the resources you need to succeed on your first try!

This is the topics covering in our free practice tools based on the CDL handbook:

·       General Knowledge – The general knowledge CDL test is taken by all applicants with 50 multiple choice questions. It covers the general topics such as the rules of having a CDL, how to drive a commercial safely, safe transportation of cargo, and pre-trip inspections.

·       Air Brakes – If you plan on driving a vehicle with air brakes, you must take the air brakes CDL test. The air brakes test concludes 25 multiple choice questions. Topics on the air brake test will include: parts of an air brake system, dual air brakes, inspecting air brake systems, and using air brakes. This test can be taken by A, B, and C license holders.

·       Hazardous materials: This endorsement test includes 30 multiple choice questions covering these topics: intent of the regulations, communication rules, loading and unloading, bulk packaging marking, driving and parking rules, and emergencies. This testing ensures that you are fully trained and qualified to deal with potentially dangerous situations.

·       Passenger Vehicles – The Passenger Endorsement Test is required for drivers who plan on driving any vehicle designed to carry 16 or more persons, including the driver. This endorsement CDL test will have 20 multiple choice questions covering the following topics: vehicle inspection, loading and trip start, on the road, after-trip vehicle inspection, prohibited practices, and use of brake-door interlocks.

·       Combination vehicles: The combination vehicles test will have 20 multiple choice questions covering on couple and uncouple trailers, pulling double/triple trailers, doubles/triples air brake checks, and inspections.

·       Double and Triple Trailer Endorsement: This endorsement test is required for any drivers pulling double or triple trailers. The test has 20 multiple choice questions on how to couple and uncouple trailers, pulling double/triple trailers, doubles/triples air brake checks, and inspections.

·       Tanker vehicles endorsement: If you are planning on driving a truck that carries liquids or liquid gas in excess of 1,000 gallons or more, this endorsement is required. The materials do not have to be hazardous

·       School bus endorsement: If you want to get a school bus endorsement, you need to have a thorough understanding of such topics as danger zones, use of mirrors, loading and unloading, emergency exit and evacuation, railroad-highway crossings, student management, antilock braking systems, and special safety considerations.

·       Pre-trip inspections: This practice test will prepare you for the internal and external portions of the vehicle inspection exam, where you will be expected to be able to walk around your vehicle, touch items and explain to the examiner why items must be inspected before a trip.

Types of Commercial Driver's License?

There are three types of CDL classes that determine the type of vehicle you may drive and how much you may tow: Class A, B and C.

·       Class A (Combination Vehicles): Any combination of vehicles with a gross combination weight rating (GCWR) of at least 26,001 pounds provided the gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of the vehicle(s) being towed exceeds 10,000 pounds. Examples include tractor-trailers.

·       Class B (Heavy Straight Vehicles): Required to operate any single vehicle that isn’t hitched to a trailer (commercial trucks that have an attached cab and cargo area with a combined weight greater than 26,000 pounds, as well as trucks with a detached towed cargo vehicle that weighs less than 10,000 pounds). Such as Straight trucks, Large buses (city buses, tourist buses, and school buses), Segmented buses.

·       Class C (Small Vehicles): Required to operate a single vehicle with GVWR of less than 26,001 pounds or a vehicle towing another vehicle that weighs less than 10,000 pounds, or transports 16 or more passengers, including the driver. Example includes Double/Tripe Trailers, Buses, Tank Trucks, HazMat Vehicles        

How may CDK endorsements are there?

There are several endorsements that can be added to your CDL as well:

  • P: Passenger Vehicles. This requires a skills and knowledge test. This endorsement allows you to drive a vehicle carrying more than a specific number of occupants, depending on your state.
  • N: Tank Vehicles. This requires a knowledge test.
  • T: Double/Triple Trailers. This requires a knowledge test
  • H: Hazardous Materials. This requires a knowledge test and the TSA Threat Assessment.
  • S: School Bus. This requires a skills and knowledge test.
  • X: Tank Vehicle/Hazardous Materials Combination.

free-nate-practice-tests-2020.description:
NATE Exam

North American Technician Excellence (NATE) is one of the most-recognized HVAC certifications in the industry. To be certificated NATE certification, technicians must pass a knowledge exam that adjusts their real-world, working knowledge of HVAC systems. NATE certification is not easy to earn. Candidates are recommended to have a minimum of one-year work experience before taking NATE exam. 
Tests cover not only basic knowledge from basic construction, electrical, and scientific knowledge but also conclude tool and safety essentials, and testing on how to achieve desired interior home comfort conditions. Additionally to those core tests, technicians then choose to earn ‘Installation’ and/or ‘Service’ certification in an array of specialty areas starting from air conditioning installation, distribution, and service to oil and gas heating installation and service.
Try our NATE practice test to pass at your first try!

Free Real Estate Practice Exam

Getting your real estate license can be the start of a new job or just merely a great way to supplement your current income. The real estate licensing exam will have about 100-150 multiple-choice questions (60-80 state-specific questions, and 80-100 questions about generally universal real estate concepts). You will have between 2-4 hours to finish your exam.

free-real-estate-practice-tests-2020.content:
Getting your real estate license can be the start of a new career or a great way to supplement your current income. But, first, you’ll need to show what you know on a test. Use our FREE Real Estate License Exam Prep app to help you prepare for the real test.

We have designed this Real Estate License Exam Prep tool to make learning process super easy and interesting. It’s proven fact that learning new things in proper way helps you remember things quickly and for long-term!

Our comprehensive real estate practice test guide is divided into the following categories:

Brokerage Responsibility and Agency Management
Contracts
Financing
Practice and Disclosures
Property and Ownership Laws
Property Valuation and Appraisal

Application features:

• Contains the complete Revision questions by the expert with detailed explanations
• Practice by topics: Test your knowledge by practicing by topics. Real Estate License Exam Prep divides topics into small parts helps you not be bored when studying.
• Mock test: Mock test simulates the real test format. When you finish the test you will see your score and review all the questions.
• New questions every time: to keep you on your toes, we randomize questions and answers each time you restart a practice test
• No internet connection and registration required
• FREE and minimum ads that annoy you

We hope you find our practice questions helpful as you study to pass your ASVAB test! If you ever have any questions, please feel free to contact us by email at abc.elearningapps@gmail.com. Happy studying and good luck as you begin this exciting step toward furthering your education!
